comment.author: 61361160@N00
comment._content: The United Empire Bank of Canada (I just found out while trying -- unsuccessfully so far -- to track down the intersection) only existed from 1906 to 1911, so the "about 1890" can't be right here.

comment.author: 25786829@N08
comment._content:
Hello,
We had the right date in the date field but not in the title.
Thank you for noticing this inconstancy.
The McCord Museum team

comment.author: 61361160@N00
comment._content: Oh of course - that makes sense! Now I just need to find out where on Yonge Street it was. With any luck it'll just appear before me later this week when I'm downtown :)

comment.author: 84987970@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lu_/]: Do you think that might be the King Edward Hotel in the middle-distance? That might make this Wellington Street, which would make some sense with the presence of banks?

comment.author: 18757234@N00
comment._content: It looks like Yonge St at Front St, looking North.  What is now the hockey hall of fame is on the left (West).

comment.author: 84987970@N00
comment._content: Oh, you could be right. It's funny, I used to work above that building for years, I'm surprised I didn't recognize it.

comment.author: 31044703@N05
comment._content: its so weird to see telephone poles in a downtown area

comment.author: 61361160@N00
comment._content: Oh of course -- this would be the same intersection today, but not the same view: www.flickr.com/photos/99906907@N00/2815969413 Toronto is full of poles -- mostly hydro poles, carrying the wires for the electrical system. Most cities buried there's a long time ago, I suppose, but we didn't.

comment.author: 36903798@N07
comment._content: The building on the left , which is the north west corner of Yonge and Front , houses the Hockey Hall of Fame.

comment.author: 65778896@N00
comment._content: Those may be cobblestones, not bricks on the street. They're stone blocks. The intersection is Yonge and Front Street. A 1908 colour-coded map showing the paving of different streets in Toronto indicates that the central part of Yonge, Front, and all of The Esplanade was paved with stone.
